Issues.Title: Dark mode class toggle not reflecting styles in Tailwind CSS v4
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

- v4.1.8

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

- Vite 6.3.5

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

- v22.3.0

**What browser are you using?**

- Chrome, Edge and Mozilla Firefox

**What operating system are you using?**

- Windows

**Reproduction URL** 

https://github.com/DARK7177/crispy-garbanzo

Attached a repo for reproduction and the unexpected behavior encountered

**Describe your issue**

Tailwind v4 styles like dark: bg-black and dark: text-white do not apply consistently across components. The background may switch, but nested text elements or buttons do not reflect the dark mode styles.

Expected behavior
Toggling the dark class should apply all dark: prefixed classes immediately, just like it worked in Tailwind v3 with darkMode: 'class'.

Actual behavior
- Some elements (e.g., <body> or wrappers) apply dark: styles correctly.
- However, elements inside custom React components do not change colors despite using dark:bg-* or dark: text-*.
- This happens even with transition-colors, duration-300, and correct class placement.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/18ac64b3-8db2-4055-9de5-0496fcc7ca2a)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/17426295-651d-4b35-b9f4-4398be316f9b)

Issues.Title: Feeling BETRAYED they removed bg-opacity-* classes
Issues.Body:
üí¢ Why Was `bg-opacity-*` Removed in Tailwind v4? Bring Back the Basics! ======================================================================== > I'm just going to say it ‚Äî the removal of `bg-opacity-*` in Tailwind v4 was **completely unnecessary** and **actively harmful** for real-world developers trying to support less-than-brand-new browsers. üë¥ The Old Way Worked. Period. ------------------------------ The old `bg-opacity-50` system: * ‚úÖ Worked everywhere (even IE11 with polyfills) * ‚úÖ Was easy to override * ‚úÖ Didn‚Äôt rely on CSS features from 2022+ * ‚úÖ Used a simple and elegant abstraction with `--tw-bg-opacity` Now we get:
Which: * ‚ùå **Uses very recent color-mix function** * ‚ùå **Breaks in older browsers** * ‚ùå **Breaks in hybrid WEBVIEW** * ‚ùå **Breaks in production when you least expect it** All to save‚Ä¶ what? One line of CSS? Was `rgba(var(--tw-bg-opacity))` too scary now? üí° You Could've Just Kept Both ------------------------------ Tailwind has utilities like `text-decoration-skip-ink`, `sr-only`, and `accent-color`. Why was **`bg-opacity-*`**, one of the most basic and widely used utilities, the one chosen for removal? At the very least, can we get: * An **official plugin** to reintroduce `bg-opacity-*` * Or an **opt-in flag** to restore legacy opacity handling * Or a **clear migration guide** for developers with backward compatibility needs üî• Devs in the Real World ------------------------- Not all of us are building greenfield apps with evergreen browser audiences. Some of us: * Build apps inside **native WebViews** that lag behind modern CSS * Need to support **embedded systems** or **older Chromium forks** * Just want our designs to degrade gracefully üò§ TL;DR -------- * Removing `bg-opacity-*` feels like a design-over-users decision * It **hurts backward compatibility** with no clear migration path * Please consider **bringing it back**, or at least **officially supporting a fallback** * Tailwind used to be "utility-first" ‚Äî now it's feeling more like "Chrome-first" * * *
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Feeling BETRAYED they removed bg-opacity-* classes" (#18192)

Issues.Title: `@source` detection not working in a web components monorepo
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

4.1.8

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

Vite 6.3.5, Lit 3.3.0

**What browser are you using?**

Chrome

**What operating system are you using?**

macOS

**Reproduction URL**

Stackblitz repro: https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-ljqtr2v2?file=packages%2Flit-consumer%2Fsrc%2Fmy-element.ts

GitHub: https://github.com/taylorfsteele/tailwind-lit-monorepo

**Describe your issue**

I have a monorepo that exports web components (via lit) from one package that is consumed by another package. I would expect the [`@source` directive would pick up](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/detecting-classes-in-source-files#explicitly-registering-sources) to pick up classes from these elements and apply them to the generated stylesheets.

The classes are not picked up or added to the stylesheet.

Oddly enough, it looks like the color is being generated correctly, but the utility isn't:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/593e8b9f-fa32-4d75-9298-d1f6f2090d33)

On build, the color and utility are generated, so in theory I could scope these to the element's shadow myself:

```
@layer components;
@layer utilities {
  .static {
    position: static;
  }
  .p-4 {
    padding: calc(var(--spacing) * 4);
  }
  .text-blue-500 {
    color: var(--color-blue-500);
  }
  .text-red-400 {
    color: var(--color-red-400);
  }
}
```

Is this a web components / shadow dom issue? Probably. But I was under the assumption that the `@source` directive would pick up these classes and then I could handle scoping them correctly.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "`@source` detection not working in a web components monorepo" (#18186)

Issues.Title: Improve upgrade migrations
Issues.Body:
This PR fixes 2 issues with the migration tool where certain classes weren't migrated. This PR fixes those 2 scenarios: ### Scenario 1 When you have an arbitrary opacity modifier that doesn't use `%`, but is just a number typically between `0` and `1` then this was not converted to the bare value equivalent before. E.g.: ```html
``` Will now be converted to: ```html
``` ### Scenario 2 Fixes a bug when a CSS function was used in a fallback value in the CSS variable shorthand syntax. In that case we didn't migrate the class to the new syntax. This was because we assumed that a `(` was found, that we are dealing with a CSS function. E.g.: ```html
^ This indicates a CSS function, we should not be converting this to `w-(--spacing(1))` ``` But if a function was used as a fallback value, for example: ```html
``` Then we also didn't migrate it, but since the function call is in the fallback, we can still migrate it. Will now properly be converted to: ```html
``` ## Test plan 1. Added a test for the first case 2. Added a test for the second case 3. Also added an integration-like test that runs all the migration steps to make sure that the `theme(‚Ä¶)` in the fallback also gets updated to `var(‚Ä¶)`. This one caught an issue because the `var(‚Ä¶)` wasn't handling prefixes correctly.

Issues.Title: Fast Refresh / Hot Reload not working with Next.js 15 and Tailwind CSS 4 ‚Äî requires full page reload on changes
Issues.Body:
I've created a fresh Next.js 15 project from scratch with the default configuration, integrating Tailwind CSS version 4 following the official setup guide.

However, fast refresh / hot reload is not working as expected:

Whenever I make any modification to components or styles, the page does not update automatically.

I have to manually refresh the entire page to see changes.

This severely impacts development productivity and debugging.

**Steps to reproduce:**

Create a new Next.js 15 project (npx create-next-app@latest)

Install and configure Tailwind CSS 4 with default settings

Start the development server (next dev)

Modify any component or style file

Observe that the page does not update automatically (no fast refresh)

**Expected behavior:**
Changes in component or style files should trigger a fast refresh / hot reload without a full page reload.

Actual **behavior**:
The browser requires a full manual reload to reflect changes.

Environment:

Next.js version: 15.x

Tailwind CSS version: 4.x

Node.js version: 20

OS: Windows 11
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Fast Refresh / Hot Reload not working with Next.js 15 and Tailwind CSS 4 ‚Äî requires full page reload on changes" (#18168)

**What browser are you using?**

Chrome

**What operating system are you using?**

Mac OS Sonoma

**Reproduction URL**

[Ok.](https://github.com/carolinecblaker/cb-com/tree/main)

**Describe your issue**

Updating a code set to tailwind 4 has resulted in some dev server breakage.

I'm under the impression that tailwind 4 is installed correctly:
- `npm run prod` produces stylesheets and code as intended
- `npm run dev` fires up a browser with styles included in referenced html

I'm under the impression that Webpack 5 is set up for Hot Module Reload (HMR):
- 'npm run dev' creates styles on-the-fly when introduced to index.html, using Tailwind 3.

**Feature I lost with upgrade:**
- 'npm run dev' to create on-the-fly tailwind styles for the browser to show when I save my work in my html file.

**What's going right:**

The dev server starts and stops without errors, and serves the page.
The dev server does serve a complete stylesheet when it starts.

Generally, "it works."

**What's not working:**

HMR (or manual) reloads appear to detect tailwindcss changes in the html, but the process of writing that style to the dev server stylesheet doesn't take place. When a tailwind  class is added to the index.html, the style doesn't display. There is a void of style, instead. I am testing this with text colors on this repository. Introduced text color classes yield a dark text treatment (unstyled) and there is no style in the inspector relating to the tailwind class I just added.

I can't get a new text color to appear without shutting down and restarting my dev server, but that does work, see "what's going right".

You may find evidence in the repo of all the ways I've tried to fix this. I apologize if this amounts to errors due to me chasing my tail. I upgraded the code set manually and followed multiple sets of directions and used at least 15 keywords to search around other peoples' questions. It does look like others have reported other Hot Reload questions recently, so it seemed like it could be a bug.
